replication_study.hypothesis: Among parliamentary democracies (1945-1999), a one-unit increase in the log of the count of parties that win ≥1 % of parliamentary seats in two consecutive elections will be associated with a positive increase in the log of economic policy dispersion (distance between the two most extreme parties), controlling for single-member-district systems and the lagged outcome.

data_plan.source_type: Comparative Manifesto Project (party manifestos) merged with Comparative Political Data Set (macro-political indicators)
data_plan.wave_or_subset: Party-election observations for 20 parliamentary democracies, 1945-1999 (same temporal scope as original, but using current CMP/CPSD releases).
data_plan.sample_size: ≈10 000 party-election observations before aggregation; ≈750 country-election units after aggregation (CPDS_final.dta preview shows 1 752 rows, get_dataset_shape).
data_plan.unit_of_analysis: Country-election (party system) after aggregation; intermediate unit is party-election.
data_plan.access_details: Both .dta files are shipped inside /app/data/original/9/python/replication_data; no additional credentials required.

qualification.explanation: The CMP and CPDS files are the canonical sources used in the original study, providing identical variables (CMP category percentages, seat shares, district magnitude).  Using the latest frozen versions offers an independent sample drawn from the same data-generation mechanism.
qualification.similarity_to_original:
• Same manifestos and coding scheme as in original (post_registration.json ‘data.source’ CMP).
• CPDS provides identical electoral-system variables (prop variable preview in CPDS_final.dta).
qualification.deviation_from_original:
• Files labelled *_final.dta appear to be newer CMP/CPDS releases (original paper covered data up to 1999—new files may include additional years; CPDS_final rows=1 752 vs. mean 5.4 parties × 20 countries × ~10 elections ≈1 000 in paper).
• Potential recodes/imputations (column ‘prop_imputed_by_datafinder’ not mentioned in original).

data_plan.notes: CMP_final.dta could not be previewed with the built-in tool (large file / newer Stata version); the Python script loads it through pyreadstat.  Ensure that the columns per303 … per701 and absseat/totseats exist; otherwise adaptation is needed.

planned_method.steps:
1. Load CMP_final.dta and CPDS_final.dta from /app/data.
2. Drop duplicate rows in each file.
3. Merge on country and election year.
4. Apply seat-share rule to identify qualifying parties and count them per election.
5. Run PCA on specified CMP categories to obtain economic policy scores for each party.
6. Compute dispersion (max–min) within each country-election and log-transform.
7. Create controls: single_member (prop==0), lagged log dispersion.
8. Regress ln_dispersion on ln_parties with controls; cluster SEs by country.
9. Save coefficient table to CSV.
planned_method.outcome_variable: ln_dispersion (log of distance between the most extreme parties on the economic dimension).
planned_method.tools_software: Python 3.11; pandas, numpy, pyreadstat, scikit-learn, statsmodels.

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Coefficient of ln_parties in the OLS model.
planned_estimation_and_test.test: Two-tailed t-test of H0: β_ln_parties = 0 (expect β>0).

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion after merge and variable creation.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Reject H0 if p<0.05 and coefficient sign is positive.

files.Andrews-Money_Replication__py.py: End-to-end Python reproduction of the original .do file.  Loads Stata data with pyreadstat, constructs variables, runs PCA and OLS with clustered SEs, and writes regression results to /app/data/original/9/python/replication_data/replication_results.csv.

codebase.notes: Script assumes CMP_final.dta contains CMP category variables prefixed ‘per’.  All paths hard-wired to /app/data for Docker compatibility.

analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare β_ln_parties (point estimate, sign, p-value) with original coefficient 0.39 (SE 0.14) reported in initial_details.txt.  Report absolute difference and whether replication remains statistically significant at 0.05.
